title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act is cited as SEC. 30B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows eligible farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit equal to 10 percent of the amount that would be allowed as a deduction for a qualified conservation contribution. The maximum credit for any taxable year is $360,000, with a special rule for joint returns. The tax credit for eligible farmers and ranchers is subject to limitations based on the amount of tax and includes an aggregation rule for controlled groups of corporations. An eligible farmer or rancher is defined as per the terms of the section. The term 'eligible farmer or rancher' is defined as an individual or C corporation meeting specific criteria related to gross income from farming. Special rules apply, including the requirement for taxpayers to elect the application of the section for the taxable year. No deduction is allowed under section 170 for a qualified conservation. The text discusses the carryforward of excess credit for qualified conservation contributions under section 170. If the credit exceeds the limitation for a taxable year, the excess is carried over to the following year. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of the tax code. Sec. 30B. Private land conservation. The amendments made by this section apply to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Increase in charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form. Section 170(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include qualified farmers and ranchers as individuals for conservation contributions. Section 170(b)(2) is also amended to exclude eligible farmers and ranchers from certain provisions. These amendments apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the estate tax exclusion for land under conservation easement is expanded. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include qualified farmers and ranchers for conservation contributions. The amendment also expands the estate tax exclusion for land under conservation easement. Additionally, a specific amendment is made to section 2031(c)(8) regarding estates of decedents dying after the enactment of the Act.
